title: 111_hr5006
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Haiti Act of 2010". It includes findings related to Haiti. Congress finds that Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, was devastated by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake on January 12, 2010. The earthquake caused massive destruction, affecting an estimated 3,000,000 people, nearly one-third of the country's population. Prior to the earthquake, Haiti was already struggling with recovery from previous natural disasters and food shortages. President Obama pledged unwavering support from the United States to aid in the recovery efforts. The global response to the earthquake in Haiti has been overwhelmingly positive, with individuals, businesses, and organizations providing support. Prior to the earthquake, there were 10,000 NGOs operating in Haiti and 3,000,000 Haitians living abroad who contribute to the local economy through remittances and skills. They have the potential to aid in reconstruction efforts. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President must call the White House Conference on Haiti by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations for Haiti's recovery. The Secretary of State and Homeland Security will plan and conduct the Conference to address ongoing challenges, promote collaboration, and identify gaps in humanitarian assistance. The White House Conference on Haiti aims to address gaps in humanitarian assistance, highlight innovative ideas for sustainable rebuilding, share best practices in development assistance, involve the Haitian diaspora and private sector in Haiti's recovery, review existing policies for long-term economic growth, and suggest changes to US immigration, trade, and foreign aid policies for a more rapid recovery. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2010, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members include officers or employees of the United States and individuals experienced in disaster relief and development in other countries. The Policy Committee, established in 2010, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are selected by the majority and minority leaders of both the House and Senate, with voting done by a majority of present members. The Policy Committee, consisting of 17 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House, acts by majority vote and is chaired by the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy. The committee's duties include making recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, proposing an agenda within 90 days of the first meeting, and suggesting delegates for the Conference. Meetings are initially called by the Co-chairs and subsequently by the chairperson. The Policy Committee, appointed by the President and Speaker of the House, will convene a Conference within 90 days. It will recommend delegates, establish their number, and form an executive committee with 3 members to work with the Conference delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES. The Co-chairs will bring together delegates from various fields without political affiliation, including representatives of governments, the Haitian diaspora, NGOs, and private sector entities. In administering this section, the Co-chairs shall provide notice to all Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other Federal departments, make proposed agendas public, provide background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed. The Co-chairs may hire additional personnel without following standard procedures, ensure balanced representation in appointments, and prevent undue influence on Conference recommendations. The Co-chairs of the Conference are responsible for ensuring that decisions are made independently, based on data and information on health and social outcomes in Haiti. They can accept gifts to support the implementation of the Act, and must maintain records of their activities. The Co-chairs can accept gifts earmarked for specific purposes and must maintain records of sources, amounts, and uses of gifts, as well as the recipients of assistance under the Act. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE.

(a) Preliminary Report.--Within 100 days after the Conference adjourns, the Policy Committee will prepare and publish a preliminary report in the Federal Register for Members of Congress and administration officials to review and provide feedback within 45 days.

(b) Final Report.--Within 6 months of the Conference adjournment, the Policy Committee will compile the views and findings of Members of Congress and administration officials into a final report. This report will include recommendations for administrative action and necessary legislation, to be published in the Federal Register and submitted to the President and Congress.

SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS.

(a) Within 1 year of the Conference adjournment, the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs will prepare and publish a status report on the recommendations from the final report in the Federal Register for the President and Congress.

(b) Every 5 years after the Conference adjourns, the Comptroller General will prepare and publish subsequent status reports on the recommendations until all are achieved. 

SEC. 9. COMMITTEE HEARINGS. The House and Senate Committees on Foreign Affairs and Foreign Relations will hold hearings on recommendations and status reports regarding Haiti recovery and development. These hearings are enacted as part of the House and Senate rules, with the recognition of the constitutional right to change such rules. The House and Senate Committees on Foreign Affairs and Foreign Relations will hold hearings on Haiti recovery and development recommendations and status reports. These hearings are conducted according to the House and Senate rules, allowing for changes to be made as needed. Authorization of appropriations for Haiti recovery and development recommendations and status reports will be conducted by the House and Senate Committees on Foreign Affairs and Foreign Relations. Authorization is granted for necessary appropriations to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts shall remain available for a year after the Conference adjourns. Any unobligated funds from the appropriations for the Act must be spent within a year after the Conference adjourns, or they will be returned to the Treasury. If the Conference does not take place before December 31, 2010, the funds will be placed in a trust fund for a future Conference on Haiti.
